content.webTitle: Southampton hopeful of major net contribution from Danny Ings

fields.headline: Southampton hopeful of major net contribution from Danny Ings
fields.bodyText: Southampton’s hierarchy toasted the arrival of Danny Ings from Liverpool late into Thursday night, as they prepare for a campaign in which they hope to right the wrongs of last season. Ralph Krueger, the chairman, organised the get‑together at a city-centre restaurant, with Gao Jisheng, the club’s Chinese owner, also present, as well as Mark Hughes, to usher in the new season, one the Saints start with renewed vigour. The manager was quick to reference the instant lift that Ings, rejected as a 10-year-old schoolboy by Southampton after being deemed too small, has provided and how he is confident his five summer signings can help them solve their goalscoring troubles. They scored fewer goals than relegated West Brom on home soil last season and recorded only four league wins at St Mary’s. Charlie Austin – Ings’s former strike-partner at Burnley, whom Southampton host on Sunday – finished last season as joint-top scorer with just seven goals and no player has reached double figures in all competitions since 2015-16. “We just wanted to increase our potential for scoring goals and creating chances,” said Hughes, who replaced Mauricio Pellegrino in March and was given a three-year contract after avoiding relegation. “Stuart Armstrong has always scored goals from midfield positions, Mo Elyounoussi we feel is going to be a real talent in the Premier League. We’ve tried to address that and clearly Danny coming in as well will complement the strikers we already have. I think we’re in a better position in terms of our attacking threat this year. “We are going to try and be better, and be better at home as well, because I think it’s important that we give our fans a little more encouragement and entertainment. At times in the last couple of seasons the fare on offer has not been what everybody wanted, for whatever reason. We’ve had a blip – and that’s what we hope it is and what we suspect it is – last year. In terms of how the season panned out, we don’t want to go down that road. We’ve made purchases with a view to making sure that doesn’t happen again.” Elyounoussi, a £16m arrival from Basel, is certainly a player for whom Southampton harbour high hopes; they have tracked him since 2012 and watched him about 30 times before making their move. Born in northern Morocco, the Norway international, who started his career playing under the former Sheffield United striker Brian Deane at Sarpsborg, has shone in the Swiss Super League since 2016 and scored 16 goals last season, including at Manchester City in the Champions League in March. But perhaps most important, Southampton has not proved the revolving door of recent years. As well as strengthening, they have retained key players, namely the full-backs Ryan Bertrand and Cédric Soares. The arrival of Angus Gunn has pushed Fraser Forster further down the pecking order, though, and the 30-year-old goalkeeper could be among those to leave on loan, with the striker Sam Gallagher and the left-back Sam McQueen also keen to play first-team football. The only sale this summer was the £15m exit of Dusan Tadic to Ajax, while the £19.2m record-signing, Guido Carrillo, and Sofiane Boufal have left on loan. Hughes said: “We haven’t had too many outgoings and I think that was important. We have added freshness to the squad as well and you have to do that. It stimulates the group and allows people that have been here longer than most to be re-energised – they see new players coming into the building and players have egos, they like to compare and contrast with those coming in, to contrast the strengths and weaknesses. That stimulates the group and is a good thing, so we are pleased where we are.” Southampton begin the new season against Burnley, a team evidently enjoying themselves after reaching the third qualifying round of the Europa League. Sean Dyche’s side did not return from Istanbul until Friday and have already played three competitive matches. Saints qualified for the group stage two years ago and, asked if they can repeat that feat this time around, Hughes’s response was bullish. “There’s no reason why we can’t,” he said. “The expectation here is that we are a top-level club, a top-half club – that’s why everybody was so disappointed last year, so we will try and achieve that again. “You just have to be ready to take advantage if one of the top six – because they do have a massive advantage in this league given the resources and quality they have – take their eye off the ball or don’t quite have the season that everybody expects. You have to be ready to be the one to take their place and that’s how we’ll approach the season. We have to try and get ourselves into a position to capitalise on that.”
